Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Acquisition of an Atomic Force Microscope
Award.AbstractNarration:
With this award from the Major Research Instrumentation (MRI) and Chemistry Research Instrumentation and Facilities (CRIF) programs, Purdue University acquires an atomic force microscope (AFM). Scanning probe instrumentation, such as a force microscope, has become central in characterizing materials at submicron scales for applications ranging from photolithographic patterning to studies of biological structure. In the past decade, substantial advances in atomic force microscopy have led to the ability to characterize materials in some cases down to the atomic scale, opening new doors in the understanding of how material structure impacts properties. In addition to its impact on research, the instrument advances the training of students at all levels in this modern technique preparing them for careers in the modern workplace.

The proposal is aimed at enhancing research especially in areas such as: (a) robust amphiphilic interfaces for energetic materials and biological structure; (b) self-assembled DNA nanomaterials for scalable nanomanufacturing; (c) functionalized collagen peptide supramolecular assemblies; (d) bioresponsive nanocarriers based on pseudorotaxanes; (e) block copolymers for organic photovoltaics; (f) energy transfer and charge carrier dynamics in solar energy conversion systems; and (g)conjugated materials and polymer composites for flexible printed electronics.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Through this award, an Asylum Cypher ES AFM was purchased for the Amy Analytical Instrumentation Facility at Purdue University. The instrument is broadly accessible, and has been utilized in research in not only the Department of Chemistry, but also the Department of Food Science, the School of Industrial Engineering, and the School of Mechanical Engineering. In the past year, users logged 842 hours of use on the instrument, performing high-resolution characterization of biomolecular systems including lipids, peptides, and DNA, as well as polymers and other soft matter interfaces. Specialized capabilities of the instrument including acquisition of Kelvin Probe Force Microscopy images have been used to examine electrical properties of interfaces with high resolution, and recently mechanical properties of soft material interfaces have been examined using force curve imaging modalities. The instrument offers the capability of in situ thermal control of the stage, which has been utilized to compare robustness of ultrathin molecular layers important in controlling physical properties of 2D materials such as graphene, and the capability to image in liquids at high resolution has been used to probe biomimetic assembly of ultranarrow gold wires relevant to next-generation nanoelectronics.

 

To date, images acquired from this instrument have been published in journals including:

Journal of the American Chemical Society 2016, 138, 4448-4457

Journal of the American Chemical Society 2017, 139, 11973-11979

ACS Applied Materials & Interfaces 2017 9, 19326−19334

ACS Applied Materials & Interfaces 2017, 9, 36409-36416

Langmuir 2018 34, 19, 5454-5463

Langmuir 2018 34, 4, 1353-1362

and has also been disseminated to the public as part of >20 scientific lectures.

Broad utility of work in utilizing data acquired using this AFM has also been recognized with industrial awards from companies including DuPont and 3M.
